questions.text: Which nerve will be involved in the following finding on rest?
questions.explanation:
Partial claw hand:
  • Clawing: Hyperextension of the metacarpophalangeal joints and flexion of interphalangeal joints.
  • Clawing is seen in 2 medial fingers only.
  • Seen in pure ulnar nerve injury.
  • Also known as the true claw hand.

Complete claw hand:
  • Clawing of all 4 fingers.
  • Seen in combined median + ulnar nerve palsy

Tardy ulnar nerve palsy:
  • Slow-onset (over years) ulnar nerve palsy.
  • Seen with cubitus valgus deformity seen in lateral epicondyle humerus fracture.

Other deformities:
  • Wasting of hypothenar muscles & intrinsic muscles of the hand.
  • Hollow inter-metacarpal spaces in hand.

Static procedure (removal)
  • Zancolli Lasso procedure

Dynamic procedures (tendon transfer)
  • Modified Bunnel technique
  • Brand’s operation
  • Fowler’s operation

questions.text: In which of the following nerve injuries is the instrument shown below used?
questions.explanation:
Type of Injury
  • Treatment

Open Injuries
  • Immediate exploration and nerve repair or grafting

Closed Injuries
  • Wait 12 weeks for recovery before exploring
  • Use EMG if no improvement; if denervation is detected, perform nerve exploration and repair or grafting

Fractures of Humerus
  • Assess for nerve injury on admission
  • If the injury appears post-manipulation or internal fixation, explore and repair or graft immediately

Recovery Management
  • Perform passive hand movements
  • Splint the wrist in extension-cock up splint:

Long-term Disability
  • Tendon transfers: pronator teres to short radial extensor, flexor carpi radialis or ulnaris to finger extensors, palmaris longus to thumb abductor

questions.text: In the orthopedics outpatient department, a female patient is presenting with difficulty sleeping at night due to experiencing numbness and tingling in the outer three digits of their hand. The symptoms improve when the patient hangs their arms from the bed. Which of the following choices accurately identifies the patient's condition and the test employed to evaluate it?
questions.correct_answer: D. Carpal tunnel syndrome, Durkan's test
questions.explanation:
Definition
  • Compression of the median nerve as it passes through the carpal tunnel in the wrist

Symptoms
  • Numbness, tingling in thumb, index, and middle fingers
  • Pain in hand and wrist, Weakness in grip
  • Symptoms often worse at night and improve during the day.
  • Advanced cases may lead to hand weakness, clumsiness, and muscle atrophy.

Structures Affected
  • Median Nerve: Compressed within the carpal tunnel, leading to symptoms and signs.
  • Flexor Tendons: The nine flexor tendons passing through the carpal tunnel can become inflamed, further compressing the median nerve.

Structures Spared
  • Thenar Eminence: Sensory loss generally spares this area because its nerve (palmar sensory cutaneous nerve) bypasses the carpal tunnel.

Clinical Signs
  • Weakness: Notable weakness in thumb abduction and opposition.
  • Atrophy: Possible atrophy of the thenar eminence in advanced cases.
  • Sensory Loss: Loss typically affects the median nerve distribution (thumb, index, middle, and radial half of the fourth digit).

Causes
  • Idiopathic- commonest cause
  • Inflammatory causes- Rheumatoid arthritis, wrist osteoarthritis
  • Post-traumatic causes- Bone thickening after a Colles' fracture
  • Endocrine causes- Myxoedema, Acromegaly

Diagnostic Tests
  • Nerve Conduction Studies (NCS) - primary diagnostic test
  • Electromyography (EMG)
  • Phalen Test: Positive if pain/paresthesias arise during wrist flexion.
  • Tinel Test: Positive if tapping over the carpal tunnel elicits symptoms.
  • Durkan test: Direct compression on Median nerve for 30 seconds. More specific than the Phalen/Tinel test.

Treatment
  • Conservative: Wrist splinting, NSAIDs, activity modification
  • Corticosteroid injections
  • Surgical: Carpal tunnel release (for severe or refractory cases)

questions.explanation:

Recovery Management

questions.text: While examining a patient with a right forearm fracture, you ask him to make a fist. The following finding is noted during this procedure. What is the sign called?
questions.explanation:
Test

Muscle tested and action

Pen test:
  • Muscle: Abductor pollicis brevis
  • Action: Abduction of thumb

Oschner clasp test:
  • Muscle: Flexor digitorum superficialis & flexor digitorum profundus
  • Action: Flexion of lateral 2 digits
  • Pointing index sign seen.

Thumb opposition:
  • Muscle: Opponens pollcis
  • Action: Opposition of thumb
  • O-sign is seen in normal patients

questions.text: The patient experiences an inability to extend their wrist upon waking up after sleeping with their arm hanging over the back of a chair. This condition is caused by
questions.explanation:
Type

Description

Prognosis

Neurapraxia

(Grade I)
  • Temporary conduction block, myelin damage only.
  • No neuroma and no degeneration.
  • Recovery is complete within 6 weeks.

Axonotmesis

(Grade II)
  • Axonal damage, connective tissue intact.
  • Neuroma in continuity.
  • Degeneration: Proximally+distally.
  • Recovery can take up to months
  • Complete recovery may not occur.
  • Motor march present

Neurotmesis

(Grade III)
  • Complete nerve disruption.
  • End or side neuroma.
  • Degeneration: Proximally+distally.
  • Spontaneous recovery never occurs.
  • Repair is required (poor recovery)

questions.text: After a surgical procedure, the patient demonstrates a particular clinical sign. Which specific nerve is likely to be damaged in this case?
questions.explanation:
Test

Muscle tested and action

Pen test:
  • Muscle: Abductor pollicis brevis
  • Action: Abduction of thumb

Oschner clasp test:
  • Muscle: Flexor digitorum superficialis & flexor digitorum profundus
  • Action: Flexion of lateral 2 digits
  • Pointing index sign seen.

Thumb opposition:
  • Muscle: Opponens pollcis
  • Action: Opposition of thumb
  • O-sign is seen in normal patients

Partial claw hand:

questions.text: When the outer sheath and nerve fiber remain intact while the inner axons are affected, this condition is referred to as
questions.explanation:
Type

Description

Prognosis

Neurapraxia

(Grade I) (Option A)
  • Temporary conduction block, myelin damage only.
  • No neuroma and no degeneration.
  • Recovery is complete within 6 weeks.

Axonotmesis

(Grade II) (Option B)
  • Axonal damage, connective tissue intact.
  • Neuroma in continuity.
  • Degeneration: Proximally+distally.
  • Recovery can take up to months
  • Complete recovery may not occur.
  • Motor march present

Neurotmesis

(Grade III) (Option D)
  • Complete nerve disruption.
  • End or side neuroma.
  • Degeneration: Proximally+distally.
  • Spontaneous recovery never occurs.
  • Repair is required (poor recovery)

questions.text: The following test is done to assess?
questions.explanation:
Test

Muscle tested and action

Pen test:
  • Muscle: Abductor pollicis brevis (Option C)
  • Action: Abduction of thumb

Oschner clasp test:
  • Muscle: Flexor digitorum superficialis & flexor digitorum profundus
  • Action: Flexion of lateral 2 digits
  • Pointing index sign seen.

Thumb opposition:
  • Muscle: Opponens pollcis

  • O-sign is seen in normal patients

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with numbness of both hands. He was asked to perform the test demonstrated below. What is the name of this test?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C  - R

Test

Description

Adson's test

A test used to evaluate thoracic outlet syndrome by checking the radial pulse while the patient rotates their head and extends their neck.

Pemberton test

A test used to assess for thoracic outlet syndrome caused by the compression of structures between the clavicle and the first rib. It involves raising both arms above the head while monitoring for symptoms.

Roos test

Also known as the "Elevated Arm Stress Test" or "Chicken Wing Test," it is used to evaluate thoracic outlet syndrome by having the patient elevate both arms, flex the elbows, and open and close their hands for several minutes.

Wright test

 The Wright test, also known as the Hyperabduction Test, is a clinical examination used to diagnose thoracic outlet syndrome (TOS). The Wright test specifically assesses for compression of the subclavian artery and the brachial plexus by the pectoralis minor muscle.
